En esta loca industria del videojuego a veces suceden cosas inexplicables, cosas que nuestra mente se resiste a asimilar, y una de ellas es la desaparición de Irrational Games y la retirada a un segundo plano de Ken Levine, ahora embarcado en proyectos "menores" y más "personales".

Y digo esto porque, tras terminar Bioshock Infinite, uno se pregunta por qué, cuál es el motivo de que 2K Games haya cerrado tan prolífico estudio. Estudio que no olvidemos tiene a sus espaldas clásicos como System Shock o Bioshock, gente con una capacidad innata para contar buenas historias y hacernos replantear nuestras convicciones políticas y religiosas. Esa clase de personas que son raras de encontrar y que convierten en magia todo lo que tocan.

Bioshock Infinite es una obra maestra del videojuego moderno, un claro exponente del potencial y la capacidad de creación de un grupo de artistas motivados y con talento. Tiene sus carencias, esas que se ven en las escenas de acción, en las que nos muestran un shooter genérico y con escasas innovaciones. Y ciertamente ahí terminan sus defectos, pues el resto del conjunto es soberbio, con una fuerza narrativa demoledora, unos personajes desbordantes de carisma, una ambientación perfecta y un apartado técnico impecable. Mención especial al diseño artístico y sonoro, difícilmente superables y que deberían convertirse en un referente, en el modelo a seguir por los demás estudios de desarrollo.

Dicho esto, es fácil suponer que lo considero un imprescindible, un must have en toda regla. No importa que no te guste el género shooter, olvídate de las etiquetas y déjate llevar por su atmósfera. La experiencia es muy satisfactoria y la diversión está asegurada... y no quiero terminar sin hablar de su final, uno de esos que te pillan por sorpresa y te dejan con la boca abierta. En resumen, un clásico total y absoluto.

Ah, y no te olvides de echarle un vistazo a los DLCs del Panteón Marino 1 y 2, que ayudan a comprender mejor la historia y el universo Bioshock. Si has jugado a los dos primeros, te encantarán.

I would like to recommend this game, but overall it just does not appeal to me. I'm with Totalbiscuit on this one. I've never really been a fan of the series, but I tried it because of the extremely good reception it has received. I was not really compelled by the story, but I will admit Elizabeth is well written but she could have been improved. 

At the start of the game I was quite intrigued, mainly because of the beautiful surroundings but things can change. 
The gunplay and overall combat don't feel good at all and it holds the game back together with some of the design, especially the friggin' shield. It's just, to quote Totalbiscuit, a "massive slaughterfest". And it really takes away from the experience of the story, which I would probably had enjoyed a lot more in another kind of genre.

The ending has been praised a lot. I think it sucked and it made me feel like I wasted 9 hours of going through the story.

I really don't know what to say about B:I... I enjoyed the combat and the sheer range of ways to dispatch bad guys (guns, potions, robots etc), and it was nice to have an interesting story to the gameplay as well.
I did get pretty annoyed at all the constant, overly religious references that just seemed to equate to more violence- as if trying to prove that religion causes violence or whatnot...
An example of why I don't know whether to click 'like' or dislike' is that while I enjoyed the combat and special skills, I was somewhat miffed when walking through a door a watching a captive man be shredded by crows. The crows then sort of became a shadowy man who tried to kill me. I enjoyed dispatching such a twisted freak only to discover that in killing him, I gained his crow killing-powers. In order to get full achievements you need to use all the 'skills' and that one disgusted me so much that I refused to use it. I guess I dislike that the game was pushing me to do deplorable things (yes, worse than just shooting the bad guys)... ;)
My response to B:I really is a personal one, especially the reasons I didn't like it. Having said that, the gameplay, graphics and general game were all very well done.
Hmmm.... Still don't know what to click Yes? No? Maybe neither! I guess that sums it up for me! :)
Unfortunately I need to click one... Hmmmm.......

This was an interesting addition to the bioshock franchise. After playing all three games the connections between them all serve the purpose of a fun and appealing mystery.

It opened with my character seated in a rowboat being taken to a secluded dock at the base of a lonely lighthouse.  Hmmm, seems familiar but I soon found that's where the most obvious Bioshock reference ended.

Columbia...

OMG, this was incredible.  I was hooked, hours melted away.  A rich, lavish, utopian world and you just knew something was going to screw it up.  That something was you.

I love that!

It was still only a DirectX 9 game but they used every bit of it.  Did I still trip over invisible curbs, get stuck in Velcro shrubbery and occasionally have to contend with controls as sluggish as an Atari 2600 joystick?
Yes, of course, just like any other DirectX 9 game but it didn't matter .  The story was good, the environment every bit as immersive as Battlefield 4 or Call of Duty.  Again, I was hooked.


I liked the way the developers let you get a feel for the place before people started shooting at you.  I also appreciated how they let you take a breath between bullets as well.  The themes were clear.  Hyper religious zealotry driven by megalomania with a side of racism just for good measure.

Fascism was there as well but more of the nationalistic breed than Andrew Ryan's corporatocracy.  The good of the state or at least the idealistic society it purported to be were paramount. 

It was engrossing.

I remember strolling through a cobblestone street with a barbershop quartet singing, "God only Knows" in 4 part harmony on the Victorian equivalent of a land speeder.  Which I accepted till it occurred to me that this particular song was actually released by the Beach Boys in 1966.  This was supposed to be 1912.
In another section of the map I heard CCR's "Fortunate Son"

Amusing.  Just an Easter Egg but it seemed to fit the now uneasy backdrop of what was rapidly becoming a dystopian world.


Just like the first game I was pulled along.  Learning new abilities and gaining new weaponry to further my cause.  Unlocking puzzles and always keeping a sharp eye out.  In games like these you learn to look in every nook and exploit every cranny. 

It's how I survived...

Twists, turns, heart wrenching morality and outright slaughter, you never knew what was coming at you.  History buffs would chuckle at the distortion of their tomes.  Stone effigies of the likes of John Wilkes Booth and  Jefferson Davis alongside George Washington.

Looming larger than them all was the primary antagonist, Zachary Hale Comstock, the Prophet as he preferred to be addressed.

So the game continued on with the story revealing itself like the layers of an onion. 

Brilliant....

Sadly, it all had to end.  The final crescendo, the answer nagging for your attention throughout the entire game was at hand.

Except...

The devs screwed it up.  Cheating me out of a hard fought and anxiously anticipated conclusion. 
Irrational Games decided to cheap out on the end and instead of leading you to a natural conclusion placing a final "God Battle" in the way of unlocking the secrets I'd invested so much time in learning.

What the hell?!

Instead of seeing the end credits I was forced to defend some blue jar on the deck of a floating air barge from hordes of invading foes I was ill-prepared to dispatch.

I was sent scurrying to YouTube to find an answer.  After a dozen attempts and just as many failures I relented.  I've been defeated by a game mechanic.  It was like getting to the last chapter of a book and finding someone had ripped out the pages and locked them in a box then thrown away the key.
Life's too short...

The game became a grind and one that took me further away from the story.  It broke the immersion and for that sin I cannot forgive Irrational games.

Again, just as in the first game and all of Bioshock 2, the idea was to protect something defenseless with less than adequate means. 

I don't have any patience for that.  Challenge? yes!  Stupid? No! 

Again I was resigned to YouTube to see what was denied me.  Gracious souls either more skilled or more lucky than I had posted the footage I would never see from my own efforts.

All of the failings that were mere annoyances became impenetrable barriers to me.  How could I go through the entire game without the need of trainers, cheats or hacks only to be thwarted at the end.  So much for being a straight shooter. 

At least you had console commands in Bioshock 1 and 2.  No such luck in Bioshock Infinite.

The final installment into the BioShock universe from Irrational Games is a home run for sure.  BioShock Infinite will tie up maybe a few loose ends in the story, but in all honesty, it will create many more questions than it answers.  The story is very complicated, but is very well written and thought-out.  The best way to compare it to the other games in the series, is that it is very different, but it is also similar.  It still feels like a BioShock game.

The graphics are very stylized, which serves the game very well I think, and proves that stylized graphics don't just belong in kids films and games.  They can be very impressive at times with sunshafts and shadows in certain areas, however my computer had a bit of trouble running it when there was smokey or firey areas.

The soundtrack is amazing as well, and they did a great job with it.

There's a lot of fun to be had in this game, however, the replayability is lacking, but I doubt anyone was expecting this game to be very replayable.  If this game is on sale, or the BioShock triple pack is on sale, be sure and pick it/them up.

S’il y avait des nuances, je mettrais 2.5/5 comme note. Ou 5/10. Ou 10/20.
 
Commençons par ce qui m’a plu :
-          Des graphismes sublimes, des vues impressionnantes
-          Une excellente localisation VF
-          On retrouve en partie le gameplay de Bioshock (fouiller tout ce qui traîne)
-          Une histoire intéressante (du moins, au début)
-          Quelques phases d’infiltration, malheureusement bien trop rares.
-          Les plus en combat (petites failles d’Elizabeth)

Et maintenant, les points qui m’ont le plus gêné :

-          Le pire : la transformation d’un FPS-RPG en Serious Sam (comprendre : des zones où on ne peut pas en sortir sans avoir flingué tout le monde (car, impossible de crocheter en combat). Je ne sais plus s’il y en a dans Bioshock 1 et 2, mais je n’y ai jamais eu cette sensation). C’est clairement ce qui m’a le plus agacé de tout le jeu. Obligé de tirer sur tout ce qui bouge, de viser une cible précise, et de mourir pour recharger ses munitions (lié au système d’arme). On s’énerve sur certains passages où on se prend des dégâts venus de nulle part, et on remeurt deux secondes après être revenu, pour finir les 20 mobs qui restent à la clé anglaise, en mode hit&run.

-          Le système d’arme : autant ça partait d’une très bonne idée, autant le peu de munitions que l’on peut trouver ou leur efficacité est à s’arracher les cheveux. Et quand on se retrouve à prendre une arme merdique car notre favorite est à court de balles…  Et sachant qu’il y a une vingtaine d’armes disponibles, avec quatre améliorations pour chaque, que l’on n’a pas assez de thunes pour tout prendre, que l’on ne sait pas laquelle sera dispo dans l’arène suivante.

-          Les pouvoirs : utilité, eh bien, pas grand-chose. Le même système est utilisé avec les armes (un pouvoir ramassé remplace celui actif), et là c’est le drame, on perd celui dont on se servait depuis le début. Impossible de le retrouver comme les armes.

-          L’aérotram : encore une bonne idée, mais finalement bofbof. Les interactions se limitent à se déplacer d’une zone à l’autre, et à sauter sur les mobs par moments. On peut aussi s’en servir en mode hit&run, mais gaffe contre des HandyMan.

-          L’IA des mobs est stupide (attaque de front. Ou pas, d’ailleurs), certaines zones sont « mortes » (comprendre : les mobs peuvent pas y aller, et on les shoot comme on veut)

-          L’histoire et les failles. Idem ici, une bonne idée, mais mal traitée. SPOILER : on se retrouve à osciller entre différentes réalités, sans savoir laquelle est la bonne, ni pourquoi les gens se souviennent d’un passage (comme si la réalité où se trouvait Elizabeth devenait la vraie), ni pourquoi on ne rencontre pas son double. Et en quoi tuer le DeWitt héros résoudrait quoi que ce soit (pourquoi pas un autre, comme celui qui deviendrait Comstock) ? Pourquoi les réalités alternatives (phénomène étudié par Lutece et indépendant de Columbia) disparaitraient suite à ce meurtre ?

-          Les passages que j’ai trouvé difficiles (pour cause de munitions, des mobs qui se soignent quand on meurt (et vu qu’on ne repop pas avec ce qu’on avait au début de l’arène…). SPOILER : Mention spéciale aux moments avec le fantôme (les trois, mais surtout la banque), les Handyman, le combat final sur le dirigeable, où nos armes sont aussi efficaces que des pistolets à bouchon contre les patriotes…

-          Le gameplay spécifique de Bioshock Infinite: les ciblages sont horribles, pour par exemple s’accrocher à l’aérotram, il faut une bonne distance avec le rail, pointer au bon endroit, insister pour qu’apparaisse la flèche verte. Idem pour les désignations de cible à la fin. Les soucis des armes/pouvoirs mentionné plus haut.

-          La liberté de Bioshock 1 et 2 a disparu. Ce n’est plus qu’une succession d’arènes reliées par des couloirs.

Je l’ai fini une fois, hors de question de recommencer.

Irrational Games создала, прямо таки, шедевр! В этой игре ты влюбишься во все, что только можно: прекрасный и красочный город Колумбия - пожалуйста; приветливые люди на улицах - есть; перестрелки, кровь и употребление сомнительных напитков, превращающих ваши руки то в щупальца, то в лапу ворона - даже это превосходно! Отдельным огромным плюсом идет сюжет - это нечто невообразимое, повествование затягивает тебя с прогулки в лодке со странными людьми и не отпускает до конца. Так он еще и затрагивает различные теории и не только из области физики! Прямо конфетка, а не сюжет. Ну а в конце хотел бы сказать о той, кто делает эту игру еще прекраснее, о той, в кого влюбились миллионы с первого взгляда - Элизабет. Я даже расписывать про нее не буду, ибо это займет вечность. Графика бесспорно на высоте. Но это достижение принадлежит создателям движка Unreal Engine, так что здесь говорить особо не о чем. Атмосфера оказалась весьма условной: нет ощущения большого города. Банально не хватает звуков атмосферы, хотя сам город визуально красив (опять же графика). Эффект bloom раздражает, поскольку он более чем на всем подряд.

Геймплей весьма однообразен. В начале игры на вас вываливают сразу все его "навороты", а потом ты ходишь с этим набором до конца  игры. 

Враги одни и те же, на протяжении всей игры. Только количество увеличивается, что здорово утомляет.

Сюжет просто ужасен. Сложно, запутанно. При этом, по мере развязки, ничего не удивляет и не восхищает. Конец непредсказуем, но настолько уныл, что ты радуешься тому, что просто наконец доиграл игру.

Играть, только ради того, чтобы посмотреть "технологический рай в облаках", как демонстрацию фантазии художников и возможностей Unreal Engine.

Писать обзор на Биошок Инфинит - мейнстрим мейнстримов, но что поделать, будем пытаться. Графика - да. Сюжет - да. Боевка - да. Играть приятно, скучать не приходится, т.к. локации меняются быстро, и игрушка проходится часов за 20 (плюс-минус, т.к. зависит от стиля игры, ведь если проходишь второй раз, то стараешься собрать всё и вся, убить всех разными способами)
Из минусов - в игре сложно умереть (на всех уровнях сложности). В Биошоке редко испытываешь нехватку патронов, солей или здоровья, ведь повсюду разбросаны аптечки, бананы, оружие, и даже у хрупких, на первый взгляд, женщин можно обнаружить боеприпасы для снайпера или поливалки. Поэтому, имхо, моим любимым эпизодом в игре стало спасение Элизабет из коготушек Соловья (когда Букера забросило в будущее). Это ж кайф, серьезно. Патронов мало, солей мало, никто здоровье не кидает, да еще и креслы-каталки с отрубленными головами выскакивают. И-де-а-ль-но. Ибо появляется настоящий интерес, игроку действительно необходимо тыкать F на каждый трупик и уголок, чтобы раздобыть немного патронов, игрок чувствует и страх, и азарт, и возбуждение одновременно. Правда, сия эйфория длится недолго. К Комстоку мы спешим уже вооруженными до зубов, сытые и просоленные (хд).
Собственно, на этом все. В остальных обзорах освещены другие моменты (за что игрокам спасибо).
Сам Биошок рекомендую.

It was good the first time but the second time....
The first time I played this game was on medium dificulty, I have to admit I don't have the best skills on FPS's, and yes it was challenging even there, mostly on the flagship tower defence, which felt even unfair to me. After passing the game, I relly enjoyed the storyline and visuals and the game was fun, then I passed Burial at sea and found myself wanting more. So I decided to give a try on 1999 mode and I don't repent I did. How you usually would play a game, you would just go running killing everything you see and progrssing, in 1999 mode you have to adopt a complete diferent strategy or die. You'll find yourself looking at every corner looing for some money, or ammo, or somthing to replenish you life. You have to stategise on how you use salts, amunition, it just feel like gameplay is totaly diferent... it was a strategy game, and if you are good stategizing the game will be much easier, and fun somehow!
There was times I was stuck in a level for hours with low ammo, low health, low salts, and the game really forces you to say, "what can I do this time to make things diferent." For my surprise I got so good at it that as the game progrssed, it felt easier and easier, until the last Handy man wasn't even a challenge anymore, and the falgship defence was a big surpise also. I expected it to be imposible hard but it really was the easyest thing on the game, and that is because I had a strategy. I realized I lost all my amuniotion in the first minutes in game so I started to panic. There were turrets on top shotting at me and there was no way I could kill them, they killed me twice, but I had saved to much money at the end thath relly didn't bother me, at the second revival I killed one last guy and then the mission changed ("meet elizabet on..."). It was a surprise to me since I had only been about 5 minutes in that mission, or at least thats wat it felt like, and I already had beaten the game, but again, it was the stategy, I had been thinking on how to beat that level for weeks since it was a real concern.

In the end I feel like the whole game should had always been like 1999 mode, a game tht makes you think solutions rather than forcing them. This makes you pay more attention to the most little of details on the game, so that in the end you end up praising the overall experience even more. This is the most fun I have had with a game in such a loooooooong time.
